headline: A Mother Again, a Generation Later
summary: Dorothy Tanksley, 68, has not slept in a bed since 2004 because of back problems. A maroon reclining chair in her living room, a gift from her daughter, serves as a bed. The lever provides the extra boost she needs to get up and into her wheelchair. ''I hurt most of the time, 24-7,'' Ms. Tanksley said recently at her home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. ''I take all kinds of things,'' she said, rattling off a pharmacy list: over-the-counter pain medications and prescriptions that include insulin for her diabetes and medication for high blood pressure, glaucoma and high cholesterol.

headline: Finally, Machines Understand Us
summary: How do you talk to a search engine? The same way you type to one. Google's new speech-recognition service for the iPhone, which I wrote about last week and which was released on Monday, understands you most accurately when you speak to it just the way you enter queries into the Google search box. So don't bother with polite formalisms like, ''What is the best pizza restaurant in San Francisco?'' Simply say, ''best pizza restaurant San Francisco.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths O'SULLIVAN VASSILIADIS, JOAN
summary: O'SULLIVAN VASSILIADIS-Joan, 82, past president of the Newswomen's Club of New York and a pioneer in championing the work of women journalists, died on September 29 at home on her favorite sofa with her husband, Archie Vassiliadis, holding her hand. Through months of fighting cancer, Joan didn't give illness the time of day. She laughed and told stories surrounded by her beloved daughters Darcy Flanders and Demitra Vassiliadis, her son-in-law Robert and her granddaughter Arlene age six, and close friends and family. In her career, Joan won many awards as a columnist for King Features Syndicate. Since the 1950s, Joan poured her talent and time into the Newswomen's Club, its Front Page Awards, and the club's scholarship board, the Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., of which she was president. The family requests donations be made to a McCormick Fund scholarship award created in Joan's honor by her longtime friend and fellow newswoman Roz Massow. Please make check payable to: Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., a tax-exempt charitable entity, Important: on check memo, please designate ''Joan O'Sullivan Scholarship.'' Send check to: Anne O'Hare McCormick Memorial Fund Inc., ATTN. Jan Paschal, treasurer, c/o Newswomen's Club of New York, 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY 10003.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Leatham, John
summary: LEATHAM--John T. Anderson, SC, age 72, died June 19, 2009 after a long illness. Born on July 4, 1936 in Chicago, IL, Jack was a graduate of Lawrence University. He served in the United States Air Force as a 1st Lieutenant and was awarded the Air Force Commendation Medal. After retiring from the service he joined the Continental Illinois Bank as a commercial lending officer. In 1968 he became Treasurer, VP-Finance for Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corp., which later became Reliance Group. He left Reliance as Executive Vice President to take over management of Medserco, Inc., an HMO management company. He continued to work in the health care industry until 1998 when he became a full-time consultant with the Common Fund. He retired in 2002. Mr. Leatham served as Director of International Capital Equipment Ltd., Vice- Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. Lukes School (New Canaan, CT), Director and Investor of ORI, Inc., and provided consulting services to the Department of Defense. He served as a Director and Member of SCHUUL's Executive Committee, an off-shore captive reinsurance company. He served on the National Board of Reading Is Fundamental. In addition, he served on the Board of Trustees of Lawrence University for many years and as Chairman of the Board from 1990-1992. He served on the Board of Trustees of the Common Fund for years and as Chairman of the Board of Common Fund Capital. Mr. Leatham is survived by his wife, Sheila Andersen Leatham of Anderson, SC; children Betsy LaFontaine (Jim) of Beverly, MA; Lisa Mason (Bill) of Darien, CT; John Leatham (Susan) of Anderson, SC; Bronwen Gay Dingeman (Jamie) of Grosse Pointe Farms, MI; and Douglas Leatham; brothers Jim Leatham of Ephraim, WI; and Jerry Leatham (Kate) of Chicago, IL; ten grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. He will be remembered as a loving husband, father and friend. Thy will be done. A memorial will be planned at a later date.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MANDEVILLE, PHILIP KEMPTON
summary: MANDEVILLE--Philip Kempton . The Board, staff and youth of the Andrew Glover Youth Program extend our deepest condolences to the family of Kempton Mandeville, our longtime board member, treasurer, and friend. For the past 25 years, Kempton gave so generously of himself to help our small community-based nonprofit and the youth we serve. With his considerable talents and easy-going disposition, he assisted us in myriad ways --working on our database, dressing up as Santa Claus at our annual Christmas party for our youth, opening his home to our youth for an annual BBQ picnic so that they could have a summer outing away from the city. Kempton was a true gem. He will be sorely missed by all of us. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family. MANDEVILLE--Philip Kempton, 52, died Wednesday, September 10, at home in Sherman, CT. Born in New York City, Kemp was the son of Hubert T. Mandeville and Ann Adams. A graduate of Fairfield Country Day School, the Hotchkiss School and St. Lawrence University, he was most recently self-employed as a financial computer consultant. Previously, he was Vice President of the Mandeville Foundation in New York City from 1985-2002. In that role, he helped support such diverse causes as The Sherman (Conneticut) Chamber Ensemble and the Andrew Glover Youth Program, an alternative-to-prison program in Manhattan. He was an active leader in many community groups: Naromi Land Trust (board, treasurer), Sherman Chamber Ensemble (board), Sherman Nursery School (board), Lake Mauweehoo Club (vice-president), Sherman Library (volunteer). He was also a member of the Yale Club of New York City. He was an avid guitar player and member of the Sherman Bluegrass Ensemble and other groups. Kemp is survived by his wife of 26 years, Nancy Gage Mandeville, and three children, Elizabeth, William, and Allison. He is also survived by his brothers Christopher, Matthew, Jonathan, William, and Ross, and his sisters Meredith Mandeville Hollis and Morgan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Andrew Glover Youth Program, Inc., 100 Centre St., Room 1541, NY, NY 10013.

summary: SCHOENFELD--Gerald . With deep sadness we note the death of this giant of the theatre world. Scott Rudin and John Barlow SCHOENFELD--Gerald. We are saddened and heatbroken by the sudden passing of our good friend of many years, Gerald Schoenfeld. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Pat, his daughter Carrie and son-in-law Fiore and his grandchildren Samuel and Julia. Frances and Alvin M. Stein SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Through both The Shubert Organization and The Shubert Foundation, Jerry raised millions of dollars for The Actors Fund, allowing us to continually provide assistance to our colleagues in need. His constant and unbending support will be greatly missed. Brian Stokes Mitchell, President Joe Benincasa, Executive Director Rudin family mourns the passing of our dear friend and partner, Gerry Schoenfeld. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Pat, daughter, Carrie, and the entire Schoenfeld and Shubert families. Our thoughts and prayers are with you during this difficult time. Jack Rudin, Chairman, Rudin Management.Co., Inc. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. It is with great sadness that we acknowledge the death of Gerald Schoenfeld. All of his friends and colleagues at Playbill mourn his passing. He was a great friend of Playbill and the Birsh family for over 40 years. We will miss him greatly. We send our condolences to his widow Pat and his entire family. His immense impact on the theatre and the theatre community will be felt for decades. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Artists, Board, Staff, Musicians and stage crews of Lincoln Center Theater sadly mourn the sudden and untimely death of our greatly admired friend and beloved chairman of the Shubert Organization, who for the last thirty-five years has fearlessly and valiantly advanced the interests of the theater, the entire theater, Broadway, the Road, off-Broadway, the notfor-profits of New York and throughout the United States, and wherever theatrical enterprise and creativity were poking their way through the surface of everyday life. The Shubert Foundation has been a fountain of hope and sustenance providing funds for theaters throughout the country with subsidies greater than those of the National Endowment for the Arts. He was an exemplary person of the theater and we extend condolences to his beloved wife Patricia, his daughter, Carrie and the grandchildren, to President of the Shubert Organization Philip J. Smith and all his colleagues at The Shubert Organization and The Shubert Foundation. Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Director John Beinecke, Chairman Linda Janklow, Chairman Emeritus John Chalsty, President SCHOENFELD--Gerald. He passed away suddenly on November 25 but he will live forever in our hearts as a husband, father, grandfather and brother beyond compare. His great love for his family -and ours for him --will be reflected in each and every memory we hold of him. He will be cherished by his family, his associates and all who knew him. Pat Schoenfeld, Carrie Schoenfeld-Guglielmi, Fiore Guglielmi, Sam Schatz, Julia Schatz and Irving Schoenfeld SCHOENFELD--Gerald. We are a stronger institution because of him. Our sympathies go out to Pat and their family, and to the staff of the Shubert Organization. Caryl Englander Chair, Board of Trustees Jeffrey A. Rosen President, Board of Trustees Willis Hartshorn Ehrenkranz Director SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Shubert Organization deeply mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and Chairman, Gerald Schoenfeld. He helped shape the course of The Shubert Organization and Broadway for over five decades with his tremendous imagination, knowledge, leadership and commitment to the art and business of theatre. His vision enhanced life in the theatre for the people who work on Broadway and beyond its reaches, as well as the audiences who enjoy Broadway shows. He cherished his role as a teacher of theatre as a member of the Columbia University School of the Arts faculty. His many accomplishments are a true testament to his great love of the theatre, and his singular humor and candor will be part of the legacy he leaves behind. He was, without a doubt, one in a million and we will sorely miss him. We extend our profound condolences to his wife Pat, his daughter Carrie SchoenfeldGuglielmi, his son-in-law Fiore Guglielmi, his grandchildren Sam Schatz and Julia Schatz, and his brother Irving. Board of Directors, Management and Employees of The Shubert Organization SCHOENFELD--Gerald. John Weidman, President Dramatists Guild of America SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Let us rather vow to internalize and uphold his vision for a healthy, diverse, and vibrant theater that remains a vital part of our larger cultural community. Judith O. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Windle, Ann
summary: WINDLE--Ann Steinbrecher, on July 30, 2009, in Madison, Indiana. Born in Chicago on July 24, 1911, educated at The Latin School in Chicago and graduated from Wellesley College in 1933. Married John T. Windle, head of reference at The Newberry Library, in 1937. Moved to Madison, Indiana to open an antiques business in 1948. Assisted by a personal donation from Eli Lilly, in 1960 she and her husband founded Historic Madison, Inc. (HMI), a preservation organization dedicated to preserving and protecting Madison's unique architectural heritage. Through their efforts 133 square city blocks were placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974, and their own house (the Shrewsbury-Windle House) was named a National Historic Landmark in 1994, followed by designation of the entire downtown as a National Historic Landmark District. Ann's tireless devotion to historic preservation at local and national levels will be remembered by all who met her. Her quick wit and amazing conversational ability, her knowledge of antiques, and her generosity in pouring drinks all left an indelible impression on countless visitors to Madison. She was proud of being a member of the first civil rights panel in Madison, and of being named a member of the Indiana Commission to the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. She was named a Sagamore of the Wabash, the highest distinction in Indiana given by the state governor. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on August 19 in the John T. Windle Auditorium in Madison. Donations may be made to Historic Madison, Inc., 500 West Street, Madison, IN, 47250.

Hers is a personal blog -- in other words, no advertising -- with about 2,000 daily subscribers, she said, and 1,500 additional ''readers.'' (One of them, Stephen Drucker, the editor of House Beautiful, hired her as a contributing editor.) Ms. Dwyer, who has been helping run the family business (which makes printing presses), turned to the blog as an outlet for her interest in design history. ''My goal,'' she said, ''is to encourage people to look to the past while embracing the new and modern. You can find a lot of inspiration in the past. It's how you present it that makes it new.'' Josh Rubin, who has silver replating let us restore and beautify your silver bbeen a Web and CD-ROM designer, started the site as a de- sign-source archive for his own use (he used blogging soft- ware, he said, because it was well-suited to making an archive). Five years later, Cool Hunting has been redesigned for advertising and, as of Wednesday, has amassed 5,152 entries. Its general theme, said Mr. Rubin, who lives in Chelsea with Mr. Orensten, two dogs and some Jean Prouve chairs, ''is the obsessive-compulsive process.'' (HMI), a preservation organization dedicated to preserving and protecting Madison's unique architectural heritage. Through their efforts 133 square city blocks were placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974, and their own house (the Shrewsbury-Windle House) was named a National Historic Landmark in 1994, followed by designation of the entire downtown as a National Historic Landmark District. Ann's tireless devotion to historic preservation at local and national levels will be remembered by all who met her. Her quick wit and amazing conversational ability, her knowledge of antiques, and her generosity in pouring drinks all left an indelible impression on countless visitors to Madison. She was proud of being a member of the first civil rights panel in Madison, and of being named a member of the Indiana Commission to the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. She was named a Sagamore of the Wabash, the highest distinction in Indiana given by the state governor. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on August 19 in the John T. summary: For decades, psychologists have warned against giving children prizes or money for their performance in school. ''Extrinsic'' rewards, they say -- a stuffed animal for a 4-year-old who learns her alphabet, cash for a good report card in middle or high school -- can undermine the joy of learning for its own sake and can even lead to cheating. But many economists and businesspeople disagree, and their views often prevail in the educational marketplace. Reward programs that pay students are under way in many cities. In some places, students can bring home hundreds of dollars for, say, taking an Advanced Placement course and scoring well on the exam.
